The Intelligent Smartphone That Thinks Big. |format=PDF |publisher=Samsung |date=2 August 2016 |url= https://news.samsung.com/global/wp-content/themes/sw_newsroom/download.php?post_id=76059&id=76234&meta_type=file |accessdate=11 October 2016}}{{cite news |url=http://www.fastcompany.com/3062419/samsungs-new-note-7-borrows-the-galaxy-s7s-curves-and-camera |title=Samsung's New Note 7 Borrows The Galaxy S7's Curves And Camera |work=Fast Company |accessdate=2 August 2016}} [[4K resolution|4K video recording]] at 30 [[frames per second|fps]], [[1080p]] at 60 fps, [[720p]] at 240 fps | front_camera = Samsung ISOCELL S54KE6 5.0 MP f/1.7 with wide-angle lens | sound = | connectivity = [[USB-C]] | other = | sar = | hac = | website = {{url|https://web.archive.org/web/20161009091334/http://www.samsung.com/global/galaxy/galaxy-note7/}} | references = |AR CORE=Coming in September}} [[File:Samsung Galaxy Note 7 rear.jpg|thumb|right|Rear of Samsung Galaxy Note 7]] The '''Samsung Galaxy Note 7''' (marketed as '''Samsung Galaxy Note7''') is a now-discontinued [[Android (operating system)|Android]] [[phablet]] [[smartphone]] that was produced and marketed by [[Samsung Electronics]]. Unveiled on 2 August 2016,{{cite news |title=Samsung will announce the Galaxy Note 7 on August 2nd |url= https://www.theverge.com/circuitbreaker/2016/7/12/12158552/samsung-galaxy-note-7-event-august-2nd |website=The Verge |publisher=Vox Media |accessdate=28 July 2016}} it was officially released on 19 August 2016 as a successor to the [[Samsung Galaxy Note 5|Galaxy Note 5]]. It was Samsung's first phone with a symmetrical connector and the last phone in the Galaxy Note Series to have a home button. Although it is the sixth main device in the [[Samsung Galaxy Note series|Galaxy Note series]], Samsung branded its series number as "7" instead of "6", so that consumers would not perceive it as being inferior to the flagship [[Samsung Galaxy S7]]. The Galaxy Note 7 is an evolution of the Galaxy Note 5 that inherited hardware components and improvements from the Galaxy S7, including the restoration of expandable storage and [[IP68]] water resistance, and new features such as a dual-sided curved display, support for [[high-dynamic-range video|high-dynamic-range (HDR) color]], improvements to the bundled stylus and new software features which utilize it, an [[iris recognition]] system, and a [[USB-C]] port. Demand for the Galaxy Note 7 on-launch was high, breaking pre-order records in South Korea and causing international releases to be delayed in some markets due to supply shortages. The Galaxy Note 7 also received positive reviews from critics, praising the quality of its construction, HDR support, as well as its streamlined user interface, although it was panned for its high price and increasing similarities in overall specifications to the main [[Galaxy S series]] phones. On 2 September 2016, Samsung suspended sales of the Galaxy Note 7 and announced an informal [[product recall|recall]], after it was found that a manufacturing defect in the phones' batteries had caused some of them to generate excessive heat, resulting in fires. A formal U.S. recall was announced on 15 September 2016. Samsung exchanged the affected phones for a new revision, which utilized batteries sourced from a different supplier. However, after reports emerged of incidents where these replacement phones also caught fire, Samsung recalled the Galaxy Note 7 worldwide on 10 October 2016, and permanently ceased production of the device on 11 October. Due to the recalls, Samsung has issued software updates in some markets that are intended to "[[Brick (electronics)|eliminate their ability to work as mobile devices]]", including restricting battery capacity, and blocking their ability to connect to wireless networks. Samsung has stated that it intends to recycle reusable silicon and components from the recalled models, and release refurbished models "where applicable". The recall had a major impact on Samsung's business in the third quarter of 2016, with the company projecting that its operating profits would be down by 33% in comparison to the previous quarter. [[Credit Suisse]] analysts estimated that Samsung would lose at least US$17 billion in revenue from the production and recall of the Galaxy Note 7. The Note 7 had the shortest life span of any Samsung phone. In July 2017, 9 months after the Note7 recall, Samsung released a refurbished version of the Galaxy Note 7 called '''Galaxy Note Fan Edition''' (marketed as '''Samsung Galaxy Note FE'''). It has a smaller battery of 3200 mAh and is supplied with [[Android Nougat]] with [[Samsung Experience]] UI, the operating system of the [[Samsung Galaxy S8|Galaxy S8]]. The successor to the Galaxy Note 7, the [[Samsung Galaxy Note 8|Galaxy Note 8]], was announced on 23 August 2017 and released almost a month later. ==Specifications== ===Hardware=== The Galaxy Note 7's hardware is similar in overall specifications and design to the [[Samsung Galaxy S7|Galaxy S7]], with a metal and glass chassis, [[IP68]] water resistance, and a [[microSD]] card slot. The Note 7 is equipped with an octa-core [[Exynos|Exynos 8890]] [[system-on-chip]] in most markets, and 4 GB of RAM. In China, Japan, and the United States, the Note 7 uses the quad-core [[Qualcomm]] [[Snapdragon 820]] instead (which supports older [[CDMA]] networks that are extensively used by wireless carriers in these markets),{{cite news |title=Samsung-powered Galaxy S7 suffers from sluggish GPU |url=http://www.zdnet.com/article/samsung-powered-galaxy-s7-suffers-from-sluggish-gpu/ |website=ZDNet |accessdate=1 September 2016}}{{cite news |title=What chip will your Galaxy S7 or S7 Edge have? |url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/3035732/what-chip-will-your-galaxy-s7-or-s7-edge-have.html |website=PC World |accessdate=21 February 2016}}{{cite web |title=Samsung Galaxy Note 7 Snapdragon 820 vs Exynos 8890: the beasts clash |url=http://www.phonearena.com/news/Samsung-Galaxy-Note-7-Snapdragon-820-vs-Exynos-8890-the-beasts-clash_id84167 |website=PhoneArena |accessdate=1 September 2016}} Unlike the S7, which uses Exynos chips in this market, Canadian models of the Note 7 also use the Snapdragon 820.{{cite web |title=Samsung’s Galaxy Note 7 runs the Snapdragon 820 in Canada rather than the Exynos 8890 chip |url= http://mobilesyrup.com/2016/08/08/samsungs-galaxy-note-7-runs-the-snapdragon-820-in-canada-rather-than-the-exynos-8890-chip/ |website=MobileSyrup |accessdate=1 September 2016}} The Note 7 uses a USB Type-C port—marking Samsung's first mobile phone with the symmetrical connector.{{cite news |title=Samsung's Galaxy Note 7 anoints USB-C as the king of ports |url=http://www.cnet.com/news/samsungs-galaxy-note-7-anoints-usb-c-as-the-king-of-ports/ |website=CNET |publisher=CBS Interactive |accessdate=1 September 2016}}{{cite news |url= https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2016/08/galaxy-note-7-hands-on-samsung-goes-full-sci-fi-with-an-iris-scanner/ |title=Galaxy Note 7 hands-on: Samsung goes full sci-fi with an iris scanner |work=Ars Technica |accessdate=1 September 2016}} The Galaxy Note 7 features a 5.7 inches (140 mm) [[1440p]] [[Super AMOLED]] display. Similarly to the "Edge" models of the S6 and S7, the display curves over the side bezels of the device; the curvature allows the Note 7 to be 2.2 millimetres (0.087 in) narrower than the Galaxy Note 5.{{cite news |title=Samsung Galaxy Note 7 arrives August 19th with curved display, iris scanner |url= https://www.theverge.com/circuitbreaker/2016/8/2/12344688/samsung-galaxy-note-7-announced-price-release-date-specs |website=The Verge |publisher=Vox Media |accessdate=1 September 2016}} The display supports [[high-dynamic-range video]], and is coated in [[Gorilla Glass 5]].{{cite news |url= https://www.theverge.com/tech/2016/8/22/12588008/galaxy-note-7-screen-replacement-gorilla-glass-5 |title=Seriously, don't drop your Galaxy Note 7 |first=Chaim |last=Gartenberg |work=The Verge |publisher=Vox Media |accessdate=1 September 2016}} As with all Galaxy Note models, the device is supplied with an [[active pen|active stylus]] branded as "S Pen". The Note 7 stylus supports 4,096 levels of pressure sensitivity and is water resistant. The Note 7 features the same 12-megapixel rear-facing camera as the S7, with a "Dual Pixel" [[image sensor]] and f/1.7 aperture lens.{{cite news |title=Samsung Galaxy S7 and S7 Edge: Curvier, faster, micro SD expansion—available March 11 |url= https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2016/02/samsung-galaxy-s7-and-s7-edge-curvier-faster-micro-sd-expansion-available-march-11/ |website=Ars Technica |accessdate=21 February 2016}} The Galaxy Note 7 also offers an [[iris recognition]] system, using a front-facing camera and infrared illumination. The iris scanner can be used for [[Lock screen|unlocking]], and as authentication for other features of the device (such as [[Samsung Pay]] and Secure Folder). A fingerprint reader is also embedded in the home button.{{cite web|title=Samsung outs detailed info on its Galaxy Note7 iris scanner|url=http://www.gsmarena.com/samsung_outs_detailed_info_on_its_galaxy_note7_iris_scanner-blog-19777.php|website=GSMArena|accessdate=1 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=Samsung doubles down on security with iris scanner in Galaxy Note 7|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/8/2/12348580/samsung-doubles-down-on-security-with-iris-scanner-in-galaxy-note-7|website=The Verge|publisher=Vox Media|accessdate=1 September 2016}} === Software === The Galaxy Note 7 is supplied with [[Android Marshmallow|Android 6.0 "Marshmallow"]] and an updated version of Samsung's proprietary [[TouchWiz]] user interface and software suite codenamed "Project Grace". It features an "always-on display" mode, which can display a clock and notifications on-screen when the device is not in use; different clock styles and support for notifications from third-party apps were added for the "Grace" version. The Screen off memo feature also leverages this mode, allowing users to write notes on the always-on display. The OS also features several new tools supporting the S Pen stylus, including translation, a [[screen magnifier]], and a [[GIF]] recording tool. The previous suite of note-taking apps were also consolidated into a single Samsung Notes app.{{cite web|title=Samsung Galaxy Note 7 review: Sleeker, simpler, better than ever|url=https://www.engadget.com/2016/08/16/samsung-galaxy-note-7-review/|website=Engadget|publisher=AOL|accessdate=1 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=New Note 7 TouchWiz interface features preview|url=http://www.phonearena.com/news/New-Note-7-TouchWiz-interface-features-preview_id83871|website=PhoneArena|accessdate=1 September 2016}} The Galaxy Note 7 introduces a security feature known as "Secure Folder"; it allows users to create a private workspace, protected by an authentication method, with separate user data and apps that are [[Sandbox (computer security)|sandboxed]] from the main system. Installed apps can be cloned into Secure Folder, and users can designate whether notifications generated by apps in the Secure Folder are displayed from outside it. Secure Folder is based on the [[Samsung Knox]] 2.7 technology, which also added the ability for enterprises to control the distribution of system updates, and improvements to [[mobile device management]] and [[Microsoft Exchange Server]] integration.{{cite web|title=Galaxy Note7 Security Enhanced with Updated Knox 2.7|url=https://news.samsung.com/global/galaxy-note7-security-enhanced-with-updated-knox-2-7|website=Samsung Newsroom|publisher=Samsung|accessdate=1 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=What you need to know about the Note 7's Secure Folder|url=https://www.cnet.com/how-to/what-you-need-to-know-about-the-note-7s-secure-folder/|website=CNET|publisher=CBS Interactive|accessdate=1 September 2016}} The device also introduces Samsung Pass, a platform allowing apps to provide biometric authentication using its iris scanner. Samsung reached partnerships with several major U.S. banks to explore the integration of Samsung Pass into their mobile apps.{{cite web|title=Samsung Pass to let you access your financial apps via your irises|url=http://www.cnet.com/news/samsung-pass-to-let-you-access-your-financial-apps-via-your-irises/|website=CNET|accessdate=1 September 2016}} == Release == Pre-orders for the Galaxy Note 7 opened the day following its unveiling, with a U.S. release on 19 August 2016. Samsung skipped the numbering of the Galaxy Note series directly from "[[Samsung Galaxy Note 5|5]]" to "7" to synchronize it with the flagship [[Samsung Galaxy S series|Galaxy S series]], and the [[Samsung Galaxy S7|Galaxy S7]] line. The company stated that consumers may have perceived the Galaxy Note models to be inferior in technology to Galaxy S models because the numbering in their names were one digit lower. Pre-orders in South Korea already broke records with 200,000 plus units pre-ordered within 2 days.{{cite web|url=http://www.androidauthority.com/galaxy-note-7-breaks-pre-order-records-708863/|title=(Update: huge demand in Canada too) Galaxy Note 7 breaks South Korean pre-order record|website=Android Authority|language=en-US|access-date=12 August 2016}} Samsung Canada stated that pre-orders in Canada were "outstanding".{{cite web|url=http://www.sammobile.com/2016/08/10/samsung-canada-says-galaxy-note-7-pre-orders-are-outstanding/|title=Samsung Canada says Galaxy Note 7 pre-orders are ‘outstanding’|last=SamMobile|website=SamMobile|access-date=12 August 2016}} The demand also forced countries like Malaysia, Netherlands, Russia and Ukraine to delay their releases to September due to shortage in supply.{{cite web|url=http://www.sammobile.com/2016/08/10/galaxy-note-7-delayed-in-malaysia-because-of-supply-shortage/|title=Galaxy Note 7 delayed in Malaysia because of supply shortage|last=SamMobile|website=SamMobile|access-date=12 August 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sammobile.com/2016/08/11/samsung-delays-galaxy-note-7-release-in-the-netherlands/|title=Samsung delays Galaxy Note 7 release in The Netherlands|last=SamMobile|website=SamMobile|access-date=12 August 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sammobile.com/2016/08/12/galaxy-note-7-release-delayed-in-russia-and-ukraine/|title=Galaxy Note 7 release delayed in Russia and Ukraine|last=SamMobile|website=SamMobile|access-date=12 August 2016}} == Reception == ''[[TechRadar]]'' complimented that the Galaxy Note 7's "rich-looking, glass-and-metal-fused design" would "really wow people who are upgrading from those old, plastic-clad Note 4 and Note 3 handsets", but noted that the curved edges of the screen infrequently caused minor issues when using the stylus. The display was considered to be vibrant and well-suited for multimedia, especially due to its HDR support. Aspects of the software were also praised, including the continued trimming of Samsung's TouchWiz suite and its streamlined settings interface, and that it already included features introduced to the stock operating system as of [[Android Nougat|Android "Nougat"]] (although still being initially supplied with Android "Marshmallow"). Of the device's new stylus-oriented features, the consolidated S Notes app, GIF recorder, and always-on display functionality were commended, but the translation tool was considered to be inferior to [[Google Translate]]. The Galaxy Note 7's battery was judged as being capable of one-and-a-half days of normal use, and it was noted that the software also featured numerous estimation and power-saving features. ''Techradar'' concluded that "If you're going to get out of the stylus, the Note 7 is an obvious choice. The iris scanner doesn't make it a convincing enough buy on its own. Otherwise, save your money and stick with the S7 Edge."{{cite web|title=Samsung Galaxy Note 7 review|url=http://www.techradar.com/reviews/phones/mobile-phones/samsung-galaxy-note-7-1325876/review|website=Techradar|accessdate=11 October 2016}} ''[[Ars Technica]]'' was critical of the Note 7 due to its many similarities to the Galaxy S7. The Note 7's refreshed design was commended for being smoother and more ergonomic than previous Samsung devices with curved screens, although the company was panned for using glass on the rear panel rather than metal. The S Pen was also criticized for feeling "cheap", describing it as a "hollow plastic tube that would feel more at home in a 100-pack of disposable [[Bic (company)|Bic]] pens than in an ultra-premium $850 smartphone". The iris scanner's implementation was panned for adding additional steps to the process of unlocking the phone in comparison to the fingerprint reader, and that it does not integrate into Android's integrated authentication platforms (making it proprietary to Samsung components). Warnings regarding looking at the sensor for too long were also considered to be "just a little scary". TouchWiz on the Note 7 was panned for consisting mainly of "'different for the sake of being different' changes that don't add much to the software experience", and make the interface less consistent with third-party software by removing elements of [[Material design]] language. In conclusion, ''Ars Technica'' doubted whether the Galaxy Note series was even necessary anymore due to its increasing similarities to the main Galaxy S line, and felt that the device was priced too high, citing Chinese vendors capable of undercutting the prices of major brands while still producing phones of similar specifications.{{cite web|title=Galaxy Note 7 review: What’s the opposite of "bang for your buck?"|url=https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2016/08/galaxy-note-7-review-whats-the-opposite-of-bang-for-your-buck/|website=Ars Technica|accessdate=16 October 2016}} ==Issues== ===Battery faults=== {{anchor|recall}} [[File:Samsung Galaxy Note 7 Bulletin (30365292175).jpg|thumb|Galaxy Note 7 security bulletin on a [[Lynx (Orlando)|Lynx]] bus in [[Orlando, Florida]]]] [[File:Information for owners of Samsung galaxy note 7 sailing from Poland to Sweden.jpg|thumb|right|Galaxy Note 7 Note security information]] Battery defects caused many Note 7 units to overheat and combust or explode.{{cite web|title=Samsung says bad batteries and rushed manufacturing doomed the Galaxy Note 7|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/1/22/14353686/samsung-galaxy-note-7-recall-reason-report|website=The Verge|publisher=Vox Media|accessdate=23 January 2017}}{{cite web|title=Samsung says two separate battery issues were to blame for all of its Galaxy Note 7 problems|url=http://www.recode.net/2017/1/22/14330404/samsung-note-7-problems-battery-investigation-explanation|website=Recode|publisher=Vox Media|accessdate=23 January 2017}}{{cite web|title=Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 over battery flaw|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/samsung-confirms-global-recall-replacement-galaxy-note-7-faulty-battery/|website=CNET|publisher=CBS Interactive|accessdate=11 October 2016}} On 10 October 2016, Samsung permanently discontinued the Galaxy Note 7 due to these repeated incidents. In the original run of devices, the battery, produced by [[Samsung SDI]],{{cite web|title=Samsung pins explosive Galaxy Note 7 on battery flaw|url=http://www.cnet.com/news/samsung-galaxy-note-7-explosion-battery-manufacturing-error/|website=CNET|accessdate=13 September 2016}} contained a design flaw that made electrodes on the top-right of the battery susceptible to bending. This weakened separation between positive and negative tabs of the battery, thus resulting in [[thermal runaway]] and [[short circuit]]s. Following an official recall on 12 September 2016, the Galaxy Note 7 was re-versioned using batteries from China-based [[Contemporary Amperex Technology]](CATL or ATL), which also supplies batteries to the [[IPhone]]. Samsung stated on 23 January 2017 that these batteries had suffered from a manufacturing defect in the welding process, which pushed electrodes up and caused damage to the separation between the positive and negative tabs. Some batteries were also missing insulation tape entirely. Samsung reported that these oversights resulted from the vendor's push to ramp up production of batteries for the replacement phones in order to meet demand. Due to the battery defects, the device is considered a [[Dangerous goods|hazmat product]], and is prohibited from being taken on-board at any airline or bus station, even if powered off.{{Citation needed|date=December 2018}} === Initial reports === On 31 August 2016, it was reported that Samsung was delaying shipments of the Galaxy Note 7 in some regions to perform "additional tests being conducted for product quality"; this came alongside user reports of batteries exploding while charging.[https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/aug/31/samsung-delays-galaxy-note-7-quality-testing Samsung delays shipments of Galaxy Note 7 for quality control testing], 31 August 2016. The Guardian. Retrieved 1 September 2016 On 1 September 2016, South Korea's [[Yonhap News Agency]] reported that Samsung was preparing to [[product recall|recall]] the device worldwide due to these battery issues. On 2 September 2016, Samsung suspended sales of the Galaxy Note 7 and announced an informal [[product recall|recall]], after it was found that a manufacturing defect in the phones' batteries had caused some of them to generate excessive heat, resulting in fires and explosions. A formal U.S. recall was announced on 15 September 2016. Samsung exchanged the affected phones for a new revision, which utilized batteries sourced from a different supplier. However, after reports emerged of incidents where these replacement phones also caught fire, Samsung recalled the Galaxy Note 7 worldwide on 10 October 2016, and permanently ceased production of the device on 11 October. Due to the recalls, Samsung has issued software updates in some markets that are intended to "[[Brick (electronics)|eliminate their ability to work as mobile devices]]", including restricting battery capacity, and blocking their ability to connect to wireless networks. A company spokesperson stated that it had received 35 reports of battery failure, which "account for less than 0.1 percent of the entire volume sold".{{cite web|title=Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 worldwide due to exploding battery fears|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/9/2/12767670/samsung-galaxy-note-7-recall-fire-risk|website=The Verge|publisher=Vox Media|accessdate=2 September 2016}} Samsung stated that the hazard was limited to a small fraction of phones manufactured, and released a tool on its website on 19 September to identify affected units by their unique [[IMEI]] numbers.{{cite web|title=How to tell if a Samsung Galaxy Note 7 is safe|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/9/19/12900530/samsung-galaxy-note-7-imei-checker|website=The Verge|publisher=Vox Media|accessdate=9 October 2016}} The [[U.S. Federal Aviation Administration]] (FAA) issued an advisory on 8 September 2016, that passengers should not turn on or charge these devices on board aircraft.{{cite web |title=FAA Statement on Samsung Galaxy Note 7 Devices |url=http://www.faa.gov/news/updates/?newsId=86424 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160909021245/http://www.faa.gov/news/updates/?newsId=86424 |archivedate=9 September 2016 |website=FAA.gov |location=United States |accessdate=8 September 2016 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} The European Aviation Safety Agency made a similar statement on 9 September, stating that "passengers are reminded of the need to inform the cabin crew when a device is damaged, hot, produces smoke, is lost, or falls into the seat structure."{{cite web |title=Passenger information on Samsung Galaxy Note 7 |url= https://www.easa.europa.eu/newsroom-and-events/news/passenger-information-samsung-galaxy-note-7 |publisher=European Aviation Safety Agency |accessdate=9 September 2016}} === First recall === On 12 September 2016, the Galaxy Note 7 was officially recalled in the U.S. by the Consumer Product Safety Commission, who advised all owners to shut down and cease all usage of the device, and return them in exchange for a replacement.{{cite news |title=Samsung formally recalls the Note 7 in the US |url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/9/15/12933410/samsung-galaxy-note-7-recall-us-cpsc |website=The Verge |accessdate=15 September 2016}} On 13 September 2016, Samsung announced in newspaper advertisements that it would release a software patch to the affected Galaxy Note 7 devices in South Korea, which prevents the device from being charged beyond 60% capacity to reduce the risk of combustion.{{cite news |title=Samsung software patch for Note 7 caps charge at 60 percent |url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/9/13/12900970/samsung-note-7-patch-software-bad-battery |website=The Verge |accessdate=13 September 2016}}{{cite news |title=Samsung Plans Software Update to Cut Galaxy Note 7 Fire Risk |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/samsung-china-recalls-early-release-galaxy-note-7s-1473853629 |website=The Wall Street Journal |accessdate=15 September 2016}} The Galaxy Note 7 was subsequently re-issued with batteries supplied by the Chinese company [[Contemporary Amperex Technology Co. Limited (CATL)|Amperex Technology Limited]] (which also serves as the main battery supplier for the [[iPhone]] line). These replacement models, which Samsung purportedly classified as being safe, had a prominent marking on their packaging to distinguish them from the first wave of recalled units,{{cite news |title=Samsung will mark replacement Note 7 devices with a blue S on the box |url=https://www.theverge.com/circuitbreaker/2016/9/9/12865966/samsung-note-7-recall-battery-mark-blue-s |website=The Verge |accessdate=13 September 2016}} and render all software battery indicators with green icons. Samsung was granted special permission by [[Google]] to allow this change, as it would normally violate the requirements of the Android Compatibility Definition Document (which must be met to license [[Google Mobile Services]] software and Android trademarks){{cite web |title=Google’s iron grip on Android: Controlling open source by any means necessary |url= https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2013/10/googles-iron-grip-on-android-controlling-open-source-by-any-means-necessary |work=Ars Technica |accessdate=8 December 2013}} for all status bar icons to only be rendered in white.{{cite news |title=Samsung’s latest Note 7 battery fix violates Android compatibility docs |url= https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2016/09/samsungs-latest-note-7-battery-fix-violates-android-compatibility-docs/ |website=Ars Technica |accessdate=19 September 2016}} Following the announcement of the recall, [[Verizon Wireless]] released a software update to Galaxy Note 7 units purchased from the carrier, which displays the aforementioned green icons on safe devices, and an embedded recall notice on affected devices when the device is plugged in. Unlike the South Korean update, it does not include a charging cut-off.{{cite news |title=Verizon releases Galaxy Note 7 software update with warning, new battery indicator |url=http://www.zdnet.com/article/verizon-releases-samsung-galaxy-note-7-software-update-with-warning-new-battery-indicator/ |website=ZDNet |publisher=CBS Interactive |accessdate=20 September 2016}} Samsung reported that 80% of devices had been replaced in South Korea, and roughly 50% in Europe and North America. Only 10%{{failed verification |date=October 2017}} of devices in the U.S. were returned, and about 50,000 devices were traded for a different model. However, Samsung stated that 95% of users chose to maintain their [[Brand loyalty|loyalty]] to the company.{{cite news |title=Galaxy Note 7 recall: About 500,000 US buyers exchanged their phones |url=http://bgr.com/2016/09/23/galaxy-note-7-recall-us/ |website=BGR |accessdate=24 September 2016}}{{cite news |title=Samsung: Have 'exploding' Galaxy Note 7s burned the brand?|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-37518681 |website=BBC News |accessdate=1 October 2016}} === Issues with replacement phones === In October 2016, several incidents occurred in which replacement Galaxy Note 7 phones still suffered from battery failure and combustion. A Galaxy Note 7 owner in [[Kentucky]] was hospitalized with [[acute bronchitis]] due to [[smoke inhalation]], after his replacement device caught fire in the early morning of 4 October. The owner told a local television station that he had received a text message not meant for him from a Samsung customer service representative, which read "Just now got this. I can try and slow him down if we think it will matter, or we just let him do what he keeps threatening to do and see if he does it".{{cite news | url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/10/9/13215728/samsung-galaxy-note-7-third-fire-smoke-inhalation | title=Samsung knew a third replacement Note 7 caught fire on Tuesday and said nothing | work=[[The Verge]] | date=9 October 2016 | agency=[[Vox Media]] | accessdate=9 October 2016 | author=Golson, Jordan}}{{cite web|title=Samsung must act fast to keep an exploding phone from blowing up its brand|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/oct/10/samsung-galaxy-note-7-exploding-phone-brand|website=The Guardian|accessdate=6 November 2016|date=10 October 2016}} On 5 October 2016, a flight preparing to depart from [[Louisville, Kentucky|Louisville]] was evacuated prior to takeoff when a passenger's replacement Galaxy Note 7, obtained from an [[AT&T]] retail outlet, began smoking and popping as they were turning it off. Samsung stated that they were working with [[Southwest Airlines]] to investigate the incident, but stated that they would be unable to confirm whether the device was a replacement model until it was recovered.{{cite news|last1=Bart|first1=Jansen|title=Smoking, popping Samsung Galaxy Note 7 prompts Southwest evacuation|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2016/10/05/samsung-galaxy-note-7-explodes-while-boarding-southwest-flight/91602698/|accessdate=5 October 2016|work=USA Today}} On 7 October 2016, a third replacement phone in [[Minnesota]] had reportedly caught fire in a similar manner.{{cite web| url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/10/8/13214272/samsung-galaxy-note-7-fire-replacement-battery-minnesota-again | title=Another replacement Galaxy Note 7 has reportedly caught fire | work=[[The Verge]] | date=8 October 2016 | publisher=[[Vox Media]] | accessdate=9 October 2016 | author=Golson, Jordan}} === Second recall and subsequent discontinuation === [[File:Samsung Galaxy Note 7 Air New Zealand.jpg|thumb|A sign at the [[Air New Zealand]] check-in counter in [[Pudong International Airport]] warning passengers not to bring Note 7 phones onto the plane.]] In response to these incidents involving replacement phones, the United States' five major wireless carriers ([[AT&T Mobility]] and [[T-Mobile US]] on 9 October, along with [[Sprint Corporation]], [[Verizon Wireless]], and [[U.S. Cellular]] on 10 October) subsequently announced that they would suspend sales of the Galaxy Note 7 until further notice, pending an investigation.{{cite news | url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/10/9/13219054/att-samsung-galaxy-note-7-stop-sales | title=AT&T halting Samsung Galaxy Note 7 sales following multiple fires with replacement phones | work=[[The Verge]] | date=9 October 2016 | agency=[[Vox Media]] | accessdate=9 October 2016 | author=Golson, Jordan}}{{cite news | url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/10/9/13220816/t-mobile-samsung-galaxy-note-7-stop-sale-recall | title=T-Mobile is second US carrier to halt Galaxy Note 7 sales, giving $25 credit to affected customers | work=[[The Verge]] | date=9 October 2016 | agency=[[Vox Media]] | accessdate=10 October 2016 | author=Golson, Jordan}}{{cite news | url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/10/10/13223972/verizon-samsung-galaxy-note-7-stop-sale-recall | title=Verizon will also stop issuing replacement Galaxy Note 7 phones | work=[[The Verge]] | date=10 October 2016 | agency=[[Vox Media]] | accessdate=10 October 2016 | author=Golson, Jordan}}{{cite web|title=Galaxy Note 7 replacement device sales suspended by U.S. Cellular|url=http://www.slashgear.com/galaxy-note-7-replacement-device-sales-suspended-by-u-s-cellular-10459491/|website=SlashGear|accessdate=10 October 2016}}{{cite web|title=Verizon, Sprint join AT&T, T-Mobile in pulling Galaxy Note 7|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/verizon-sprint-join-at-t-t-mobile-galaxy-note-7-replacement-fire-exploding-pull/|website=CNET|accessdate=10 October 2016}} On 10 October 2016, Samsung officially announced that it had "[asked] all carrier and retail partners globally to stop sales and exchanges" of the Galaxy Note 7, and urged all owners to power them off and "take advantage of the remedies available, including a refund at their place of purchase".{{cite web|title=Samsung stops Galaxy Note 7 sales, owners should 'power down'|url=https://www.engadget.com/2016/10/10/samsung-stops-galaxy-note-7-sales-owners-should-power-down/|website=Engadget|accessdate=10 October 2016}} On 11 October 2016, Samsung announced that it would permanently cease production of the Galaxy Note 7 in the interest of customer safety.{{cite web|title=The Galaxy Note 7 is dead|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/10/11/13202608/samsung-galaxy-note-7-discontinued|website=The Verge|publisher=Vox Media|accessdate=11 October 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-37618618|title=Samsung permanently stops Galaxy Note 7 production|date=11 October 2016|work=[[BBC News]]}} Samsung began issuing special kits to package the devices for returns; they consist of an [[antistatic bag]] that the phone is to be inserted into, and three layers of boxes—the last of which is lined with [[High-temperature insulation wool|ceramic fibre]] paper for fire protection. The shipping box also contains instructions explicitly stating that they are not to be shipped by air.{{cite web|title=Samsung sending out fireproof return boxes for the Note 7|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/10/11/13246020/samsung-note-7-fireproof-return-boxes|website=The Verge|publisher=Vox Media|accessdate=14 October 2016}} Samsung stated to [[Vice Media|Vice]]'s ''Motherboard'' that it would not repair or refurbish any of the returned phones, and that the company would "safely dispose" of them.{{cite web|title=Samsung will 'dispose of' recalled Note 7 phones, won't repair or refurbish them|url=https://www.theverge.com/circuitbreaker/2016/10/12/13257504/samsung-galaxy-note-7-disposal|website=The Verge|publisher=Vox Media|accessdate=14 October 2016}} Following Samsung's actions, the [[Rwanda]] Utilities and Regulatory Authority and the [[United States]]' Consumer Product Safety Commission issued official recalls of all units of the Galaxy Note 7. These recalls ban the sale and distribution of any Galaxy Note 7 phone within these countries.{{cite web |last=Dobie |first=Ales |title=It's official — two days after Samsung canceled the phone, it's been recalled (again) in the United States. |work=Android Central|date=13 October 2016 |url= http://www.androidcentral.com/cpsc-issues-second-galaxy-note-7-recall-23-new-fires-involving-replacement-notes |accessdate=13 October 2016}}{{cite web|title=The CPSC officially recalls all Note 7 devices, citing 23 new reports since first recall|url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/10/13/total-recall-2/|website=TechCrunch|accessdate=13 October 2016}}{{cite news |last=Mwai |first=Collins |title=Rwanda Bans Troublesome Galaxy Note 7 |work=The New Times (Rwanda) |date=13 October 2016 |url=http://www.newtimes.co.rw/section/article/2016-10-13/204408/ |accessdate=13 October 2016}} The British [[Royal Mail]] and British courier company [[Parcelforce]] announced that they would not accept or deliver any parcels containing a Galaxy Note 7.{{cite news |url= https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/1930258/royal-mail-refusing-to-deliver-flammable-samsung-galaxy-note-7-devices/ |title=Samsung Galaxy Note 7 recalled but the Royal Mail is REFUSING to deliver them |date=11 October 2016 |publisher=The Sun |location=United Kingdom}}{{cite web|title=Service Updates|url=http://www.parcelforce.com/service-updates|website=Parcelforce Worldwide (archive.org)|accessdate=27 June 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170606105637/http://www.parcelforce.com/service-updates|archivedate=6 June 2017|df=dmy-all}} Online marketplaces [[eBay]] and [[Gumtree]] also began to pull listings selling Galaxy Note 7 devices.{{cite web|title=eBay is removing Samsung Galaxy Note 7 auctions after phone fires|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/ebay-removing-samsung-galaxy-note-7-auctions-after-phone-fires-1585786|website=International Business Times|accessdate=13 October 2016}} After the suspension of sales, [[Oculus VR]] issued an update to its software for the [[Samsung Gear VR]] [[virtual reality headset]], which blocks its use with the Galaxy Note 7 for safety reasons. The headset had been included with some units of the phone as a promotional offer.{{cite web|title=Oculus disables Gear VR on Galaxy Note 7 over safety fears|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/10/11/13240098/galaxy-note-7-gear-vr-support-disabled|website=The Verge|accessdate=11 October 2016}} On 14 October 2016, the U.S. [[Federal Aviation Administration]] and the [[United States Department of Transportation|Department of Transportation]]'s [[Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration]] banned the Note 7 from being taken aboard any airline flight, even if powered off.{{cite web|title=The Galaxy Note 7 will be banned from all US airline flights|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/10/14/13288978/samsung-galaxy-note-7-flight-ban-faa-us|website=The Verge|accessdate=14 October 2016}}{{cite web|title=U.S. Department of Transportation bans Galaxy Note 7 from all flights|url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/10/14/u-s-department-of-transportation-bans-galaxy-note-7-from-all-flights/|website=TechCrunch|accessdate=14 October 2016}} [[Qantas]], [[Virgin Australia]] and [[Singapore Airlines]] issued similar bans,{{cite news |title=Samsung Galaxy Note 7: Qantas, Virgin and Singapore Airlines ban phone from flights |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-10-15/airlines-ban-samsung-galaxy-note-7-on-flights/7936102 |accessdate=15 October 2016 |work=ABC News |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=15 October 2016}} while [[Transport Canada]] issued a notice stating that the Galaxy Note 7 was banned from flights under Special Provision 137 prohibitions, banning the carriage of damaged or defective lithium-ion batteries onto flights.{{cite web |title=NOTAM - Samsung Galaxy Note 7 |url=http://www.tc.gc.ca/eng/tdg/page-1295.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161018220747/http://www.tc.gc.ca/eng/tdg/page-1295.html |archivedate=18 October 2016 |date=14 October 2016 |publisher=Transport Canada |accessdate=16 October 2016 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} In response to these air travel bans, Samsung announced that it would set up dedicated kiosks at selected airports, to allow travelers to exchange or receive a refund for their Galaxy Note 7 on-site before they depart, rather than having their phone confiscated by security or airport staff.{{cite web|title=Samsung Sets Up Note 7 Exchanges at Major U.S. Airports|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-10-18/samsung-sets-up-note-7-exchanges-at-major-airports-in-the-u-s|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=18 October 2016}} In December 2016, a [[Virgin America]] flight from San Francisco to Boston was nearly diverted mid flight after it was discovered that a passenger on the plane had been operating a Wi-Fi hotspot with the [[SSID]] "Samsung Galaxy Note7_1097". However, it was later discovered that the hotspot was a hoax, and that no passenger had actually brought a Galaxy Note 7 on board.{{cite web|title=Virgin flight delayed by Galaxy Note wi-fi hoax|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-38404711?ocid=socialflow_twitter|website=BBC News|accessdate=2 January 2017}}{{cite web|title=A flight was late because someone named their Wi-Fi hotspot ‘Galaxy Note 7’|url=https://www.theverge.com/circuitbreaker/2016/12/22/14063842/samsung-galaxy-note-7-virgin-america-flight-sfo|website=The Verge|publisher=Vox Media|accessdate=2 January 2017}} ==== Disabling of functionality ==== On 4 November 2016, the [[New Zealand Telecommunications Forum]] announced that all Galaxy Note 7 phones would be banned from use on local mobile networks (Vodafone NZ, Spark NZ, 2degrees and around a dozen MVNO's) beginning 18 November, enforced via IMEI blacklist.{{cite web|title=Explosive Galaxy Note 7 gets blacklisted from New Zealand networks|url=https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2016/11/explosive-galaxy-note-7-gets-blacklisted-from-new-zealand-networks/|website=Ars Technica|publisher=Conde Nast|accessdate=6 November 2016}} On 30 November 2016, Samsung announced that Galaxy Note 7 devices would be banned from Australian wireless networks effective 15 December 2016.{{cite web|title=Samsung works with Australian carriers to cut Note 7 network access|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/samsung-australian-telcos-carriers-cut-note-7-network-access-telstra-optus-vodafone/|website=CNET|publisher=CBS Interactive|accessdate=15 December 2016}}{{cite web|title=Galaxy Note7 units still in use in Australia will be disconnected from the mobile networks on December 15|url=http://www.gsmarena.com/galaxy_note7_units_still_in_use_in_australia_will_be_disconnected_from_the_mobile_networks_on_decemb-news-21947.php|website=GSMArena|accessdate=15 December 2016}} In December 2016, Samsung announced its intent to cripple the functionality of unreturned Galaxy Note 7 phones in Canada and the United States via software updates. In Canada, an update restricted charge capacity, and blocked the phone from connecting to any wireless networks, nor use Wi-Fi or Bluetooth. In the United States, the update blocked the devices from being recharged in order to "[[Brick (electronics)|eliminate their ability to work as mobile devices]]".{{cite web|title=Samsung is basically making the Note 7 unusable in Canada|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/12/7/13876968/samsung-galaxy-note-7-canada-cutting-off-wireless-connections|website=The Verge|publisher=Vox Media|accessdate=8 December 2016}}{{cite web|title=Samsung confirms it will render the US Note 7 useless with next update|url=https://www.theverge.com/circuitbreaker/2016/12/9/13897794/samsung-galaxy-note-7-update-shut-down-inoperable|website=The Verge|accessdate=9 December 2016}} Verizon announced that it would refuse to distribute this update due to the "added risk this could pose to Galaxy Note 7 users that do not have another device to switch to" because it would "make it impossible to contact family, first responders or medical professionals in an emergency situation", especially during the holiday season. On 18 December 2016, Verizon announced that they would be distributing the update on 5 January 2017.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/verizon-wireless-agrees-to-brick-samsung-galaxy-note-7/|title=Verizon Wireless agrees to brick Samsung Galaxy Note 7|newspaper=CNET|access-date=18 December 2016}} Sprint also stated that it would not distribute this update until January 2017.{{cite web|title=Verizon refuses to release update that would kill Samsung’s Note 7|url=https://www.theverge.com/circuitbreaker/2016/12/9/13899852/verizon-refuses-samsung-note-7-update|website=The Verge|publisher=Vox Media|accessdate=9 December 2016}} Verizon later announced that it would redirect all outgoing calls (excluding emergency calls) made on unreturned Galaxy Note 7 devices to a service hotline demanding that they be returned, and threatened to charge customers a fee equaling the total retail cost of the phone if they refused to comply.{{cite web|title=Galaxy Note 7 recall refuseniks face new action|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-38664325|website=BBC News|accessdate=18 January 2017}} On 9 January 2017, Samsung released another update in South Korea, blocking the device from being charged beyond 15%.{{Cite news|url=http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/business/2017/01/04/59/0502000000AEN20170104004300320F.html|title=Samsung to limit Note 7 battery charge to 15 pct in S. Korea from Monday|publisher=Yonhap News|date=4 January 2017| access-date=4 January 2017}} On 24 March 2017, Samsung released yet another update for South Korea users, barring charging of the Galaxy Note 7.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/samsung-galaxy-note-7-charging-disabled/|title=Samsung disabling Galaxy Note 7's battery charging in South Korea|publisher=CNET|date=24 March 2017|access-date=24 March 2017}} ==Aftermath== ''[[The Verge]]'' criticized Samsung's overall handling of the battery faults and recall, arguing that the company had initially delivered unclear messaging over whether the devices were still safe to use, as well as its slow communication with the U.S. [[Consumer Product Safety Commission]], which had the capacity to issue an official recall in the U.S. The arguments were based on data released on 13 September 2016 by the research firm [[Apteligent]], which stated that Galaxy Note 7 usage had been "almost exactly the same" since the announcement of the exchange program.{{cite news |url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/9/15/12926308/galaxy-note-7-recall-samsung-fumbled-usage |title=Everyone is still using their Galaxy Note 7 as Samsung fumbles its global recall |first=James |last=Vincent |date=15 September 2016 |work=The Verge |publisher=Vox Media |accessdate=15 September 2016}} ''The Verge'' also noted that the U.S. government's ban on taking Galaxy Note 7 phones aboard airline flights was "perhaps unprecedented", acknowledging that only the ban of [[Self-balancing scooter|hoverboards]] by individual airlines for similar reasons—an entire class of products (albeit one that was "admittedly fire-prone because of cheap materials")—came close to a legal ban for a single consumer product in terms of overall magnitude. Kyle Weins of ''[[Wired.com]]'' felt that Samsung switched to non-removable batteries in order to imitate the industrial design of [[Apple Inc.|Apple]], after having used removable batteries on many of its past models (such as the [[Samsung Galaxy Note 4|Galaxy Note 4]]). He argued that this design decision exacerbated the battery faults of the Note 7, by requiring users to replace the entire phone as opposed to just the battery. He suggested that in the future, Samsung could "lead the pack" by switching back to removable batteries, as with other "responsible" OEMs such as [[HP Inc.]] and [[LG Electronics]].{{cite web |title=Opinion: Gluing Batteries Down Made It Worse For Samsung |url=https://www.wired.com/2016/10/samsung-exploding-note-7/ |website=Wired.com |accessdate=11 October 2016}} Analysts argued that the recall had hurt Samsung's brand, and would likely cause the company to lose its market share to competitors, including [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] and [[Google]] (which had recently unveiled their [[iPhone 7]] and [[Pixel (smartphone)|Pixel]] models), and other Android vendors. [[Credit Suisse]] analysts predicted that the recall and discontinuation would cause Samsung to lose nearly US$17 billion in revenue.{{cite web |last1=Cuthbertson |first1=Anthony |title=How much money has the Galaxy Note 7 debacle cost Samsung? |url=http://www.newsweek.com/how-much-samsung-galaxy-note-7-cost-samsung-recall-508852 |accessdate=11 October 2016 |work=Newsweek}} On 12 October 2016, Samsung revised its earnings forecast for the third quarter of 2016, estimating a 33% drop in operating profits in comparison to the second quarter of 2016, and revenue expectations cut by [[South Korean won|₩]]2 trillion to ₩47 trillion (US$41.8 billion).{{cite web|title=Samsung slashes profit forecast by a third following Galaxy Note 7 debacle|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/10/12/13254634/samsung-earnings-forecast-cut-q3-2016|website=The Verge|publisher=Vox Media|accessdate=13 October 2016}} On 18 October 2016, McCuneWright LLP sued Samsung and filed a proposed class-action lawsuit over its handling of the recall, stating that the company had "failed to reimburse consumers for monthly costs associated with owning an unusable Note 7".{{cite web|title=Samsung sued over Galaxy Note 7 recall|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/samsung-lawsuit-galaxy-note-7-recall-class-action/|website=CNET|accessdate=18 October 2016}} Samsung was also criticized by customers affected by the exploding phones, who alleged that the company was refusing to compensate them for property damage caused by the explosions.{{cite web|title=Samsung owners furious as company resists paying up for Note 7 fire damage|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/oct/19/samsung-galaxy-note-7-fire-damage-owners-angry|website=The Guardian|accessdate=20 October 2016}} In the wake of the recall, Samsung, as well as [[UL LLC]], [[Exponent (consulting firm)|Exponent]], and [[TÜV Rheinland]] performed internal testing and analysis to determine the exact causes of the defects. Samsung released its official findings on 23 January 2017.{{Cite web|url=https://news.samsung.com/global/infographic-galaxy-note7-what-we-discovered|title=[Infographic] Galaxy Note7: What We Discovered|date=23 January 2017|website=Samsung Newsroom|language=en|access-date=27 June 2017}} Concurrently, the company announced that all of its future battery-operated products would become subject to an "enhanced" eight-point inspection and testing protocol, including stricter visual inspections, as well as charge and discharge tests, Total Volatile Organic Compound tests, and accelerated usage tests. An advisory board of academics was also formed.{{cite web|title=This is how Samsung plans to prevent future phones from catching fire|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/1/22/14353458/samsung-eight-step-battery-test-exploding-smartphones|website=The Verge|accessdate=23 January 2017}} Concerns were also raised over the creation of [[electronic waste]] resulting from Samsung's announced plan to destroy all returned phones, rather than recycle and refurbish them into new products.{{cite web|title=Here's what Samsung is doing with all those recalled Galaxy Note 7s|url=http://www.techradar.com/news/heres-what-samsung-will-do-with-the-recalled-galaxy-note-7s|website=Techradar|publisher=Future plc|accessdate=14 October 2016}} In February 2017, ''[[Korea Economic Daily]]'' reported that Samsung had been considering refurbishing the Galaxy Note 7 into a modified version with lower battery capacity, and targeted toward markets such as Vietnam. A representative of Samsung India denied these reports.{{cite web|title=Samsung Refutes Reports of Plans to Sell Refurbished Galaxy Note 7 Phones in India|url=http://gadgets.ndtv.com/mobiles/news/samsung-refutes-reports-of-plans-to-sell-refurbished-galaxy-note-7-phones-in-india-1662060|website=Gadgets360|publisher=NDTV|accessdate=22 February 2017}} [[Greenpeace]] disrupted a press conference by Samsung at [[Mobile World Congress]] to protest the company's unclear plans for the recalled devices. On 27 March 2017, Samsung announced that it now intends to extract reusable parts such as metal, semiconductors, and cameras from the recalled devices, and market refurbished devices "where applicable".{{cite web|title=Samsung confirms the Note 7 is coming back as a refurbished device|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/3/27/15072560/samsung-note-7-refurbished-device-recyling-announced|website=The Verge|accessdate=27 March 2017}}{{cite web|title=Greenpeace protesters interrupted Samsung’s MWC presentation|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/2/26/14744524/greenpeace-protesters-interrupted-samsungs-mwc-presentation|website=The Verge|publisher=Vox Media|accessdate=27 March 2017}} After the discontinuation of the Note 7, some features in the device (such as Samsung Pass, Secure Folder, S Pen related features, and Grace UX) were eventually made available in Marshmallow (e.g. [[Samsung Galaxy A8 (2016)|Galaxy A8 (2016)]], [[Samsung Galaxy A series|Galaxy A (2017) series]] and Galaxy Tab A 10.1 (2016)) and Nougat (e.g. [[Samsung Galaxy Note 5|Galaxy Note 5]] (via software update), [[Samsung Galaxy S8|Galaxy S8/S8+]] and Galaxy C Pro series) == Samsung Galaxy Note Fan Edition (FE) == {{anchor|FE}} [[File:Samsung Galaxy Note FE (3).png|thumb|Samsung Galaxy Note Fan Edition]] In June 2017, the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' reported on Samsung's plan to refurbish its inventory of recalled phones and release them with a new model designation of Galaxy Note FE, with the "FE" referencing "Fan Edition." The phone was also rumored to be named as the Note 7R, with the R referencing "refurbished". This phone was released on the 7th of July in South Korea, with limited availability in other countries to follow, and a price of $610; being a $255 discount from the price of the Note 7.{{cite news|last1=Amadeo|first1=Ron|title=Samsung’s fiery Galaxy Note 7 to rise from the ashes as the “Fandom Edition”|url=https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2017/06/samsungs-fiery-galaxy-note-7-to-rise-from-the-ashes-as-the-fandom-edition/|accessdate=30 June 2017|publisher=Ars Technica|date=28 June 2017}} The Fan Edition has a smaller battery of 3200 mAh and multiple safety features. It has a "Fan Edition" logo on the back. The software is identical to that of the S8. It has a similar UI and includes [[Bixby (virtual assistant)|Bixby]] home and reminders but not the whole Bixby assistant.{{cite web|last1=Maggio|first1=Edoardo|title=Samsung is bringing back the Galaxy Note 7 with a new 'Fan Edition'|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/samsung-is-bringing-back-the-galaxy-note-7-with-a-new-fan-edition-2017-7|website=Business Insider|accessdate=3 July 2017|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170703115801/http://www.businessinsider.com/samsung-is-bringing-back-the-galaxy-note-7-with-a-new-fan-edition-2017-7|archivedate=3 July 2017|deadurl=no|language=en|date=3 July 2017|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.phonearena.com/news/Samsung-Galaxy-Note-7-FE-fan-edition-official-Note-7-hardware-Galaxy-S8-UI-Bixby_id95605|title=Samsung Galaxy Note Fan Edition uses Note 7 hardware and specs, but sports Galaxy S8 UI including Bixby|date=2 July 2017}} Samsung introduced an eight-point battery check after the Note7 to make sure all of their batteries are safe for new and current devices in production. There have been no reported incidents of an S8/S8+ catching fire after their release as the first new flagship device to go through the eight-point battery check. There have been no reported incidents of the successor Note 8 catching fire either.{{cite web|last1=Siddiqui|first1=Aamir|title=Samsung Officially Launches the Galaxy Note 7 Fan Edition in Korea|url=https://www.xda-developers.com/samsung-officially-launches-the-galaxy-note-7-fan-edition-in-korea/|website=xda-developers|accessdate=4 July 2017|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170704144727/https://www.xda-developers.com/samsung-officially-launches-the-galaxy-note-7-fan-edition-in-korea/|archivedate=4 July 2017|deadurl=no|language=English|date=3 July 2017|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|last1=Maggio|first1=Edoardo|title=A component teardown shows the Samsung Galaxy Note Fan Edition is just a Note 7 with a smaller battery|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/ifixit-teardown-galaxy-note-fan-edition-is-note-7-smaller-battery-2017-7|website=Business Insider|language=en}} After the Fan Edition was released in [[South Korea]], the Galaxy Note FE was also released in select countries in [[Asia]] starting in October 2017.{{cite news |title=Samsung Galaxy Note FE pre-orders begin today in Malaysia
